moves.4... Nc6 5. O-O Nf6: All four knights have been developed.
moves.8. d3: Blocks in my bishop, better is Be3.
moves.8... Re8 9. a4 h6 10. Be3 Qd7: Two pieces are aiming at h3, and one of them is the most powerful piece on the board.
moves.11. d4: Threatening d5, also opening up my bishop.
moves.11... exd4 12. Bxd4: This turns out to be a swap.
moves.12... Nxd4 13. Nxd4 d5: Now I get the bishop for knight.
moves.15... Nxd5 16. Nxd5 Qxd5: ?? This seems okay, but this is what should happen now: Qxd5! exd5 Bh5! wins bishop or rook for bishop.
moves.17. Qxd5 exd5 18. Bf3: ?? At this moment, I don't see Bh5.
moves.20. Rxe8+ Rxe8 21. Bxe8: Now I am +5, and after my rook gets active, black is helpless.
moves.23. Re1: ! The bishop is pinned, not to a piece, but to checkmate.
moves.23... b6: Now black must push all his pawns, until he is forced to move the king or bishop.
moves.28. cxd4 cxd4 29. Kf1: Now I must use my king to stop black from queening.
moves.35. Re8#: Checkmate, extremely simple, the bishop protects the rook and stops Kf7, while the rook delivers the mate. Thanks for reading! Hope you enjoyed.
